class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Millennials enjoy sports just as much as members of other generations. It’s the way they consume sports that matters.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology media and telecommunications/media and entertainment/our insights/we are wrong about millennial sports fans/we-are-wrong-about-millennial-sports-fans.pdf" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_blank" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="we-are-wrong-about-millennial-sports-fans" data-layer-report-name="we-are-wrong-about-millennial-sports-fans>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-438 KB)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Many sports executives fear</strong> that the root cause of declining ratings and aging audiences is the disengagement of millennials from live sports.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote1" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="8e502365-322e-4e4d-a386-1d11128418f1" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">1</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote1" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="8e502365-322e-4e4d-a386-1d11128418f1"><span></span>Nielsen defines millennials as people born 1980–1996, Generation X as 1965–1979, and baby boomers as 1947–1964. We define “live sports” as traditional sports, excluding e-sports and other competitive, nontelevised games.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  “[Millennials] don’t watch TV, they don’t have TVs or subscribe to cable. So we have to bring that audience in,” Robert Kraft, principal owner of the New England Patriots football franchise, recently said.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote2" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="2bc0a7fd-d627-4a58-bb5f-af50dc217fd9" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">2</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote2" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">2.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="2bc0a7fd-d627-4a58-bb5f-af50dc217fd9"><span></span>Giovanni Bruno, “Patriots owner Robert Kraft says OTT is the future of the NFL,” <em>TheStreet</em>, June 23, 2017, thestreet.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  Brian Hughes, senior vice president of audience intelligence and strategy at MAGNA Global USA put it this way: “[Their] increased interest in short-term things, like stats and quick highlights… has funneled some young viewers away from TV.”<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote3" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="6d05dd09-e53e-492d-b538-c494969fe24d" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">3</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote3" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">3.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="6d05dd09-e53e-492d-b538-c494969fe24d"><span></span>David Broughton and John Lombardo, “Going gray: Sports TV viewers skew older,” <em>Sports Business Journal</em>, June 5, 2017, sportsbusinessdaily.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  Jeramie McPeek, former vice president of digital and brand strategy for the Phoenix Suns, cites: “It is smartphone and tablet usage by younger people who are on Snapchat or Instagram all day long and watching a lot of videos on YouTube and Netflix.”<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote4" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="e08c89e1-fee8-44f4-ae63-23ac70d7b5f0" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">4</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote4" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">4.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="e08c89e1-fee8-44f4-ae63-23ac70d7b5f0"><span></span>Ibid.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>TV trends—including declining ratings, cord shaving, and cord cutting—present a long-term challenge for traditional sports (see sidebar “The ratings slide”). But the belief that millennials are to blame is misplaced.</p>
<h2>We aren’t losing fans, we are fighting short attention spans</h2>
<p>With so many sports options across so many screens, fans of all ages—not just millennials—are watching fewer games and quitting them faster.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The ratings slide</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Ratings for major sports have dropped over the past two years, raising fears of a millennial exodus from TV. NFL regular-season viewership is down by 17 percent on ESPN; it has dropped by 7 percent on NBC, 8 percent on FOX, and 6 percent on CBS.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6e0632cc-11b7-4e54-ba66-c3472fe277e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6e0632cc-11b7-4e54-ba66-c3472fe277e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">What’s next for the NFL?” <em>Sports Business Journal</em>, February 13, 2017, sportsbusinessdaily.com.</span></span></span></a></span> NHL regular-season ratings were down 11 percent last year, NBA down 8 percent, and MLB down 11 percent. Studio shows such as <em>Pardon the Interruption</em> and <em>SportsCenter</em> were even harder hit, losing double-digit percentages in 2017.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a69de613-8d30-4577-937f-bf56d94a4a73"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a69de613-8d30-4577-937f-bf56d94a4a73" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">ESPN at the crossroads,” MoffettNathanson, July 10, 2017, moffettnathanson.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Sports are holding up better than TV viewership overall; for example, in May 2017, total day ratings (including sports) were down 14 percent for broadcast networks and 9 percent for cable networks versus the prior year, according to MoffettNathanson analysis. However, that comparison provides little comfort. Sports are more dependent on live viewing than are other categories of video entertainment, which can recoup some of the lost TV engagement from time-shifted DVR replays and video on demand. Dramas and comedies have also benefited more from over-the-top services, such as Amazon Prime Video, Hulu, and Netflix, as an additional window for time-shifted viewing.</p>
<p>At the same time, the TV audience for most sports is aging faster than the US population. The average NASCAR viewer is now 58 years old, up 9 years since 2006. TV viewers of the NHL are seven years older on average than they were at that time, for NFL, they are 4 years older, MLB 4 years older, and NBA 2 years older. (For comparison, the average American is 2.7 years older than in 2000.)</p>
<p>However, TV ratings for sports have significant upside (5 percent to 20 percent, depending on the event) from out-of-home viewing, based on new Nielsen measurements for bars, restaurants, hotels. Out-of-home sports viewers also tend to be younger, which could change our view of the speed at which audiences are aging. New measurements of digital viewing could also provide more precision, but they are unlikely to change the overall conclusion: as fans go digital, they shift to shorter sessions fragmented among proliferating viewing options.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>From our analysis of Nielsen data, in the 2016–2017 regular season, National Football League (NFL) ratings among millennials declined 9 percent. However, the number of millennials watching the NFL actually increased from the prior season (from 65 percent to 67 percent of all millennials). The ratings decline was caused by an 8 percent drop in the number of games watched and a 6 percent decline in the minutes watched per game (down to 1 hour 12 minutes per game). The same was true for Generation X for the NFL (a 6 percent decline in ratings, no change in reach) and for millennials and Generation X for the most recent Major League Baseball (MLB), National Basketball Association (NBA), and National Hockey League (NHL) seasons. Overall reach for sports on TV hasn’t declined; ratings have dropped because fans are watching fewer and shorter sessions.</p>
<p>In a world with so many sports options across so many screens, sports fans of all ages are clicking away from low-stakes or lopsided games.</p>
<h2>Millennials versus Generation X: The wrong way to segment sports fans</h2>
<p>As sports executives seek to build new direct-to-consumer channels, we find that age is an ineffective way to segment and target digital sports fans. Older generations (Gen Xers in particular) are adopting digital technology almost as fast as millennials, and fans’ online behaviors are far better signals of purchase intent. The following are a few important findings:</p>
<p><em>Millennials are sports fans too</em>. Although more Gen Xers than millennials follow sports closely (45 percent versus 38 percent), the gap disappears for English Premier League (EPL), Major League Soccer, NBA, Ultimate Fighting Championship, and college sports, where support among millennials is as high or higher than among Generation X<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote5" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="58034b0a-9fe3-40f6-bbed-85d668ceb416" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">5</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote5" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">5.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="58034b0a-9fe3-40f6-bbed-85d668ceb416"><span></span>Online survey of 465 adults, ages 18–53, June 2017. We defined fans as those watching or following sports at least once every two weeks.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  (Exhibit 1). Furthermore, the gender gap is closing: 45 percent of millennial sports fans are women versus 41 percent for Generation X.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p><em>Most millennials have cable</em>. As of November 2016, 78 percent of millennials had cable, satellite, or telco TV service at home, according to Nielsen. That’s pretty close to the 84 percent of Gen Xers with cable.</p>
<p><em>It’s not about getting older; it’s about having kids</em>. It’s true that on average, millennials watch less TV. They watched 28 percent fewer hours per week of TV in 2016 than people their age did in 2010, whereas Generation X viewing slipped by only 8 percent over the same period. However, when Nielsen segments millennials into those living with parents, those living on their own, and those starting their own families (at age 27, all three segments are about equal in size), big differences show up. Millennials with kids watch 3 hours and 16 minutes of live TV per day, fully 55 percent more than millennials living on their own and just 14 percent less than Gen Xers under 49. Another important finding: millennials living on their own spend 15 percent more time out of their homes and are 31 percent more likely to own a multimedia device than millennials with kids, and they watch 6 percent more live sports on TV than millennial parents do.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote6" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="8239213e-c1c9-46a5-8bf9-5d958fe9ac2a" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">6</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote6" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">6.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="8239213e-c1c9-46a5-8bf9-5d958fe9ac2a"><span></span>Millennial life stages: Impact on technology, services and media behavior, Nielsen, November 2015. Figures use Nielsen Portable People Meters, which do not measure out-of-home viewing when the TV is inaudible.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p><em>Millennials still watch live games</em>. Millennial sports fans watch almost as many live games per week as Generation X sports fans (3.2 games per week versus 3.4 games per week) and the same amount of highlights and other nonlive sports (about 32 minutes per day). And more believe they have increased the amount of live sports they watch on TV than those who think they have decreased (30 percent versus 25 percent, similar to the rates for Generation X).</p>
<p><em>Everyone’s digital</em>. Virtually everyone in Generation X owns a smartphone, as do millennials (95 percent versus 97 percent).<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote7" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="ae8fce3d-a5d0-4290-bb60-0c8165083f6f" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">7</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote7" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">7.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="ae8fce3d-a5d0-4290-bb60-0c8165083f6f"><span></span>Millennials are top smartphone users,” Nielsen Mobile Insights, November 15, 2016, nielsen.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span>  The two groups own multimedia devices (36 percent versus 40 percent) and use streaming or subscription video on demand (68 percent versus 75 percent) at nearly the same rates. And they both spend over 5 hours per day on smartphones and PCs (Exhibit 2). Somewhat surprisingly, mobile video usage averages under 15 minutes per day, but PC video consumption is almost four times as high.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>A difference of degree: Streaming and social media</h2>
<p>For all the similarities in technology adoption and viewing behaviors, millennials differ from their parents’ generation in the following two ways that matter to sports-rights holders:</p>
<p><em>Millennials stream sports more often</em>. In our research, millennial sports fans report using streaming web sites and apps (for example, NBCSports.com, Twitter, and WatchESPN) almost twice as much as Generation X (56 percent versus 29 percent). They are also more likely to admit to using unauthorized sports streaming sites, such as Reddit streams (20 percent versus 3 percent). A recent BBC survey found that 65 percent of British millennials stream EPL matches illegally at least once per month.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote8" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="980c6536-db72-49d6-87f0-6aecccb4a4bf" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">8</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote8" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">8.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="980c6536-db72-49d6-87f0-6aecccb4a4bf"><span></span>Premier League: Third of fans say they watch illegal streams of matches—survey,” BBC Sport, July 4, 2017, bbc.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p><em>Millennials are social fans</em>. While millennials and Gen Xers use sports sites and apps equally, significantly more millennials follow sports on social media. For example, 60 percent of millennial sports fans check scores and sports news on social media versus only 40 percent for Generation X (Exhibit 3). Twice as many millennials use Twitter, and five times as many use Snapchat or Instagram for that purpose. Facebook is the leading social platform for both groups, but YouTube dominates sports highlights for millennials (edging out ESPN.com). Overall YouTube engagement per monthly unique viewer has reached 37 minutes per day for 18–24 year olds versus just 15 minutes per day for Generation X.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote9" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="7d5012da-5b22-4096-8c15-ac45480b3dc4" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">9</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote9" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">9.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="7d5012da-5b22-4096-8c15-ac45480b3dc4"><span></span>“US Internet: From cat videos to the NFL—are we at the tipping point for online video?” MoffettNathanson, June 28, 2017, moffettnathanson.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/media%20and%20entertainment/our%20insights/we%20are%20wrong%20about%20millennial%20sports%20fans/svgz_we_are_wrong_millennial_sports_fans_ex-3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Despite millennials’ heavier use of streaming and social media for sports, the gap is closing. As of 2016, millennials spent 24 percent of their media time on social media compared with Generation X at 22 percent and boomers at 20 percent, and Gen Xers and boomers are growing their social-media usage at higher rates than millennials.<span class="footnote-holder"><a rel="#footnote10" class="link-footnote footnote-wrapper" aria-describedby="47e7403e-b3c5-4f7d-af55-c80eacda18a9" tabindex="0" aria-label="footnote" style="cursor: pointer;"><sup class="footnotesup">10</sup><span class="notch-wrapper"><span class="notch"></span></span><span id="footnote10" class="tooltip"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">10.</span><span class="footnote-text" id="47e7403e-b3c5-4f7d-af55-c80eacda18a9"><span></span>“Sean Casey, <em>Nielsen 2016 social media report</em>, Nielsen, January 2017, nielsen.com.</span><span class="clear"></span></span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></a></span> </p>
<h2>Implications: Targeting digital sports fans</h2>
<p>Given the similar trends in sports viewing among millennials and Generation X, how should sports marketers target digital fans? Here are five strategies:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Target mobile viewers of live streams</em>. In predicting the number of live sports events watched per week, we found that generational difference (that is, millennials versus Gen Xers) was not statistically significant. However, those who watch live sports on mobile watch 20 percent more live sports events than those who do not.</li>
    <li><em>Convert the pirates</em>. Fans who admit to watching unauthorized streams watch 22 percent more games (across all platforms) than those who do not. Although it may be impractical to target these users, they are evidently avid sports fans who could be a primary target for new direct-to-consumer streaming services.</li>
    <li><em>Target moms</em>. In our sample, male sports fans with children watched 14 percent fewer live games than those without, but women with children watched 24 percent <em>more</em> sports events than those with no kids.</li>
    <li><em>Promote tickets on social media</em>. Teams know to target fans making over $100,000 per year (51 percent of whom attend live games versus 40 percent of those earning under $100,000 per year), but they may not know that 56 percent of fans who follow athletes or teams on social media attend games (versus only 30 percent of fans who do not).</li>
    <li><em>Highlights are the gateway to subscription video</em>. Fans who consume over 30 minutes per day of sports highlights are three times as likely to subscribe to sports over-the-top services as fans who do not. Fans who follow teams and players on social media are also more than twice as likely to subscribe as those who do not. Use of sports apps and mobile sites is a leading indicator; 52 percent of fans in our sample who check news and articles on sports sites and apps also watch live sports streams versus only 22 percent of those who do not.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Implications: Innovating the digital sports experience</h2>
<p>The problem of declining attention spans will not be solved merely by replatforming TV video for PCs and mobile devices. As sports marketers develop new digital products—including services for live-streamed events, highlights, fan commentary, news, and analysis—they should design for new, digital behaviors that cut across generations:</p>
<ul>
    <li>shorter viewing sessions (for example, with whip-around viewing and quick navigation to other games)</li>
    <li>one-click tune-in access from social media or search, prompted by alerts on high-stakes game situations (rather than appointment viewing)</li>
    <li>convenient access (for example, the ability to watch any game for user’s favorite team or player or fantasy player, regardless of the TV network on which they are broadcast)</li>
    <li>rapid, simple sign-on (ideally using fingerprints or other biometrics) and payment</li>
    <li>fast, intuitive social sharing of game highlights and fan chatter</li>
    <li>quick navigation between fantasy sports rosters and live streams, especially for avid daily fantasy sports players (and sports bettors)</li>
    <li>fun, quick social contests to keep casual fans engaged with live games</li>
</ul>
<p>Generation X wanted its MTV. Millennials have fear of missing out. Both generations are consuming digital sports voraciously, at the expense of traditional TV viewing. Sports marketers who target the right digital behaviors (rather than traditional viewer segments) and develop digital products to take advantage of them will build stronger fan bases than ever before.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article originally appeared in <em>Sports Business Journal</em>, September 2017.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><a href="/our-people/dan-singer"><strong>Dan Singer</strong></a> is a partner in McKinsey’s New York office and leads the Global Sports and Gaming Practice.

has funneled some young viewers away from TV.\u0026rdquo;\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote3\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote3\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eDavid Broughton and John Lombardo, \u0026ldquo;Going gray: Sports TV viewers skew older,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSports Business Journal\u003c/em\u003e, June 5, 2017, sportsbusinessdaily.com.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Jeramie McPeek, former vice president of digital and brand strategy for the Phoenix Suns, cites: \u0026ldquo;It is smartphone and tablet usage by younger people who are on Snapchat or Instagram all day long and watching a lot of videos on YouTube and Netflix.\u0026rdquo;\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote4\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e4\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote4\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e4.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eIbid.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTV trends\u0026mdash;including declining ratings, cord shaving, and cord cutting\u0026mdash;present a long-term challenge for traditional sports (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The ratings slide\u0026rdquo;). But the belief that millennials are to blame is misplaced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWe aren\u0026rsquo;t losing fans, we are fighting short attention spans\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith so many sports options across so many screens, fans of all ages\u0026mdash;not just millennials\u0026mdash;are watching fewer games and quitting them faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar ratings]]\n\u003cp\u003eFrom our analysis of Nielsen data, in the 2016\u0026ndash;2017 regular season, National Football League (NFL) ratings among millennials declined 9 percent. However, the number of millennials watching the NFL actually increased from the prior season (from 65 percent to 67 percent of all millennials). The ratings decline was caused by an 8 percent drop in the number of games watched and a 6 percent decline in the minutes watched per game (down to 1 hour 12 minutes per game). The same was true for Generation X for the NFL (a 6 percent decline in ratings, no change in reach) and for millennials and Generation X for the most recent Major League Baseball (MLB), National Basketball Association (NBA), and National Hockey League (NHL) seasons. Overall reach for sports on TV hasn\u0026rsquo;t declined; ratings have dropped because fans are watching fewer and shorter sessions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a world with so many sports options across so many screens, sports fans of all ages are clicking away from low-stakes or lopsided games.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMillennials versus Generation X: The wrong way to segment sports fans\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs sports executives seek to build new direct-to-consumer channels, we find that age is an ineffective way to segment and target digital sports fans. Older generations (Gen Xers in particular) are adopting digital technology almost as fast as millennials, and fans\u0026rsquo; online behaviors are far better signals of purchase intent. The following are a few important findings:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMillennials are sports fans too\u003c/em\u003e. Although more Gen Xers than millennials follow sports closely (45 percent versus 38 percent), the gap disappears for English Premier League (EPL), Major League Soccer, NBA, Ultimate Fighting Championship, and college sports, where support among millennials is as high or higher than among Generation X\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote5\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e5\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote5\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e5.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eOnline survey of 465 adults, ages 18\u0026ndash;53, June 2017. We defined fans as those watching or following sports at least once every two weeks.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e (Exhibit 1). Furthermore, the gender gap is closing: 45 percent of millennial sports fans are women versus 41 percent for Generation X.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMost millennials have cable\u003c/em\u003e. As of November 2016, 78 percent of millennials had cable, satellite, or telco TV service at home, according to Nielsen. That\u0026rsquo;s pretty close to the 84 percent of Gen Xers with cable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s not about getting older; it\u0026rsquo;s about having kids\u003c/em\u003e. It\u0026rsquo;s true that on average, millennials watch less TV. They watched 28 percent fewer hours per week of TV in 2016 than people their age did in 2010, whereas Generation X viewing slipped by only 8 percent over the same period. However, when Nielsen segments millennials into those living with parents, those living on their own, and those starting their own families (at age 27, all three segments are about equal in size), big differences show up. Millennials with kids watch 3 hours and 16 minutes of live TV per day, fully 55 percent more than millennials living on their own and just 14 percent less than Gen Xers under 49. Another important finding: millennials living on their own spend 15 percent more time out of their homes and are 31 percent more likely to own a multimedia device than millennials with kids, and they watch 6 percent more live sports on TV than millennial parents do.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote6\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e6\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote6\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e6.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eMillennial life stages: Impact on technology, services and media behavior, Nielsen, November 2015. Figures use Nielsen Portable People Meters, which do not measure out-of-home viewing when the TV is inaudible.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMillennials still watch live games\u003c/em\u003e. Millennial sports fans watch almost as many live games per week as Generation X sports fans (3.2 games per week versus 3.4 games per week) and the same amount of highlights and other nonlive sports (about 32 minutes per day). And more believe they have increased the amount of live sports they watch on TV than those who think they have decreased (30 percent versus 25 percent, similar to the rates for Generation X).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEveryone\u0026rsquo;s digital\u003c/em\u003e. Virtually everyone in Generation X owns a smartphone, as do millennials (95 percent versus 97 percent).\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote7\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e7\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote7\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e7.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eMillennials are top smartphone users,\u0026rdquo; Nielsen Mobile Insights, November 15, 2016, nielsen.com.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The two groups own multimedia devices (36 percent versus 40 percent) and use streaming or subscription video on demand (68 percent versus 75 percent) at nearly the same rates. And they both spend over 5 hours per day on smartphones and PCs (Exhibit 2). Somewhat surprisingly, mobile video usage averages under 15 minutes per day, but PC video consumption is almost four times as high.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eA difference of degree: Streaming and social media\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor all the similarities in technology adoption and viewing behaviors, millennials differ from their parents\u0026rsquo; generation in the following two ways that matter to sports-rights holders:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMillennials stream sports more often\u003c/em\u003e. In our research, millennial sports fans report using streaming web sites and apps (for example, NBCSports.com, Twitter, and WatchESPN) almost twice as much as Generation X (56 percent versus 29 percent). They are also more likely to admit to using unauthorized sports streaming sites, such as Reddit streams (20 percent versus 3 percent). A recent BBC survey found that 65 percent of British millennials stream EPL matches illegally at least once per month.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote8\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e8\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote8\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e8.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003ePremier League: Third of fans say they watch illegal streams of matches\u0026mdash;survey,\u0026rdquo; BBC Sport, July 4, 2017, bbc.com.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMillennials are social fans\u003c/em\u003e. While millennials and Gen Xers use sports sites and apps equally, significantly more millennials follow sports on social media. For example, 60 percent of millennial sports fans check scores and sports news on social media versus only 40 percent for Generation X (Exhibit 3). Twice as many millennials use Twitter, and five times as many use Snapchat or Instagram for that purpose. Facebook is the leading social platform for both groups, but YouTube dominates sports highlights for millennials (edging out ESPN.com). Overall YouTube engagement per monthly unique viewer has reached 37 minutes per day for 18\u0026ndash;24 year olds versus just 15 minutes per day for Generation X.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote9\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e9\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote9\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e9.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;US Internet: From cat videos to the NFL\u0026mdash;are we at the tipping point for online video?\u0026rdquo; MoffettNathanson, June 28, 2017, moffettnathanson.com.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eDespite millennials\u0026rsquo; heavier use of streaming and social media for sports, the gap is closing. As of 2016, millennials spent 24 percent of their media time on social media compared with Generation X at 22 percent and boomers at 20 percent, and Gen Xers and boomers are growing their social-media usage at higher rates than millennials.\u003ca href=\"#\" class=\"link-footnote\" onclick=\"return false;\" rel=\"#footnote10\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e10\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote10\" style=\"display: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e10.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;Sean Casey, \u003cem\u003eNielsen 2016 social media report\u003c/em\u003e, Nielsen, January 2017, nielsen.com.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eImplications: Targeting digital sports fans\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the similar trends in sports viewing among millennials and Generation X, how should sports marketers target digital fans? Here are five strategies:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTarget mobile viewers of live streams\u003c/em\u003e. In predicting the number of live sports events watched per week, we found that generational difference (that is, millennials versus Gen Xers) was not statistically significant. However, those who watch live sports on mobile watch 20 percent more live sports events than those who do not.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eConvert the pirates\u003c/em\u003e. Fans who admit to watching unauthorized streams watch 22 percent more games (across all platforms) than those who do not. Although it may be impractical to target these users, they are evidently avid sports fans who could be a primary target for new direct-to-consumer streaming services.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTarget moms\u003c/em\u003e. In our sample, male sports fans with children watched 14 percent fewer live games than those without, but women with children watched 24 percent \u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e sports events than those with no kids.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePromote tickets on social media\u003c/em\u003e. Teams know to target fans making over $100,000 per year (51 percent of whom attend live games versus 40 percent of those earning under $100,000 per year), but they may not know that 56 percent of fans who follow athletes or teams on social media attend games (versus only 30 percent of fans who do not).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHighlights are the gateway to subscription video\u003c/em\u003e. Fans who consume over 30 minutes per day of sports highlights are three times as likely to subscribe to sports over-the-top services as fans who do not. Fans who follow teams and players on social media are also more than twice as likely to subscribe as those who do not. Use of sports apps and mobile sites is a leading indicator; 52 percent of fans in our sample who check news and articles on sports sites and apps also watch live sports streams versus only 22 percent of those who do not.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eImplications: Innovating the digital sports experience\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe problem of declining attention spans will not be solved merely by replatforming TV video for PCs and mobile devices. As sports marketers develop new digital products\u0026mdash;including services for live-streamed events, highlights, fan commentary, news, and analysis\u0026mdash;they should design for new, digital behaviors that cut across generations:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eshorter viewing sessions (for example, with whip-around viewing and quick navigation to other games)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eone-click tune-in access from social media or search, prompted by alerts on high-stakes game situations (rather than appointment viewing)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003econvenient access (for example, the ability to watch any game for user\u0026rsquo;s favorite team or player or fantasy player, regardless of the TV network on which they are broadcast)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003erapid, simple sign-on (ideally using fingerprints or other biometrics) and payment\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efast, intuitive social sharing of game highlights and fan chatter\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003equick navigation between fantasy sports rosters and live streams, especially for avid daily fantasy sports players (and sports bettors)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efun, quick social contests to keep casual fans engaged with live games\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGeneration X wanted its MTV. Millennials have fear of missing out. Both generations are consuming digital sports voraciously, at the expense of traditional TV viewing. Sports marketers who target the right digital behaviors (rather than traditional viewer segments) and develop digital products to take advantage of them will build stronger fan bases than ever before.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article originally appeared in \u003cem\u003eSports Business Journal\u003c/em\u003e, September two years, raising fears of a millennial exodus from TV. NFL regular-season viewership is down by 17 percent on ESPN; it has dropped by 7 percent on NBC, 8 percent on FOX, and 6 percent on CBS.[[Footnote 1]] NHL regular-season ratings were down 11 percent last year, NBA down 8 percent, and MLB down 11 percent. Studio shows such as \u003cem\u003ePardon the Interruption\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eSportsCenter\u003c/em\u003e were even harder hit, losing double-digit percentages in 2017.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSports are holding up better than TV viewership overall; for example, in May 2017, total day ratings (including sports) were down 14 percent for broadcast networks and 9 percent for cable networks versus the prior year, according to MoffettNathanson analysis. However, that comparison provides little comfort. Sports are more dependent on live viewing than are other categories of video entertainment, which can recoup some of the lost TV engagement from time-shifted DVR replays and video on demand. Dramas and comedies have also benefited more from over-the-top services, such as Amazon Prime Video, Hulu, and Netflix, as an additional window for time-shifted viewing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, the TV audience for most sports is aging faster than the US population. The average NASCAR viewer is now 58 years old, up 9 years since 2006. TV viewers of the NHL are seven years older on average than they were at that time, for NFL, they are 4 years older, MLB 4 years older, and NBA 2 years older. (For comparison, the average American is 2.7 years older than in 2000.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, TV ratings for sports have significant upside (5 percent to 20 percent, depending on the event) from out-of-home viewing, based on new Nielsen measurements for bars, restaurants, hotels. Out-of-home sports viewers also tend to be younger, which could change our view of the speed at which audiences are aging. New measurements of digital viewing could also provide more precision, but they are unlikely to change the overall conclusion: as fans go digital, they shift to shorter sessions fragmented among proliferating viewing options.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The ratings slide"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n
